title: Abraham Skorka
text:
Abraham Skorka (born July 5, 1950, in <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>) is an <a href="Argentine">Argentine</a> <a href="biophysicist">biophysicist</a>, <a href="rabbi">rabbi</a> and book author. Abraham Skorka is rector emeritus of the <a href="Seminario%20Rab%C3%ADnico%20Latinoamericano">Seminario Rabínico Latinoamericano</a> in Buenos Aires, the rabbi of the Jewish community Benei Tikva, professor of biblical and <a href="rabbinic%20literature">rabbinic literature</a> at the Seminario Rabínico Latinoamericano and honorary professor of <a href="Hebrew%20Law">Hebrew Law</a> at the <a href="Universidad%20del%20Salvador">Universidad del Salvador</a>, Buenos Aires.
Career.
Abraham Skorka held with the <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Buenos%20Aires">Archbishop of Buenos Aires</a> <a href="Jorge%20Mario%20Bergoglio">Jorge Mario Bergoglio</a>, later <a href="Pope%20Francis">Pope Francis</a>, a series of <a href="inter-religious">inter-religious</a> talks on topics such as <a href="God">God</a>, <a href="fundamentalism">fundamentalism</a>, <a href="atheists">atheists</a>, <a href="death">death</a>, <a href="holocaust">holocaust</a>, <a href="homosexuality">homosexuality</a>, and <a href="capitalism">capitalism</a>. The dialogues alternately took place at the seat of the bishop and at the Jewish Community Benei Tikva. They were published in a book titled "Sobre el Cielo y la Tierra" (On Heaven and Earth).
In 1973 he graduated from the Seminario Rabínico Latinoamericano with ordination as a rabbi.
In 1979 he was awarded his doctorate in <a href="Chemistry">Chemistry</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Buenos%20Aires">University of Buenos Aires</a>. Skorka has published scientific papers in the field of biophysics and numerous articles in the field of <a href="Biblical">Biblical</a> and <a href="Talmudic">Talmudic</a> research.
He received a doctorate "<a href="honoris%20causa">honoris causa</a>" from the <a href="Jewish%20Theological%20Seminary%20of%20America">Jewish Theological Seminary of America</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
In 2010 the <a href="Universidad%20Cat%C3%B3lica%20Argentina">Universidad Católica Argentina</a> awarded him a doctorate "<a href="honoris%20causa">honoris causa</a>", the first time in <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a> that a Catholic university gave this title to a rabbi.
In May 2017, Skorka published an approbation in regards to the <a href="Center%20for%20Jewish%E2%80%93Christian%20Understanding%20and%20Cooperation%23Orthodox%20Rabbinic%20Statement%20on%20Christianity">Orthodox Rabbinic Statement on Christianity</a> entitled "" which was published two years beforehand by the <a href="Israel">Israel</a>-based <a href="Center%20for%20Jewish%E2%80%93Christian%20Understanding%20and%20Cooperation">Center for Jewish–Christian Understanding and Cooperation</a> (CJCUC).
In 2018-2019, he serves as Visiting University Professor at the Institute for Jewish-Catholic Relations at Saint Joseph's University in Philadelphia, PA.
